content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; in about 39 minutes we will be having a design meeting about the perf.rlo site.

@simulacrum and I met yesterday and spoke a bit about the agenda for this meeting. I didn't have time to write it up yesterday, but here is what I've come up with this morning: https://hackmd.io/MqzuXVWnS22pVZgnFS5Tlg
(Its pretty open-ended)
I am tracking size of rustc & rust-std components, and found them to be highly correlated with perf regression & improvements.
instruction counts aren't a good indication of wall-clock performance?
@oliver not always. Heres' a nice example where icount is the same, but ther's 2x wall clock diff: https://users.rust-lang.org/t/building-hash-map-is-cheaper-than-doing-lookups/55044/21?u=matklad
right
hi @T-compiler/meeting , sorry I'm a few minutes late!
so, I don't think I'd say we have an "agenda", per se. What I have are notes on things we could dicsuss: https://hackmd.io/MqzuXVWnS22pVZgnFS5Tlg

Oh, first off, lets do three minutes for

Announcements
@simulacrum can you remind me when we need to get beta backports in by?
I would like to see them approved by end of day today, and then we'll be wrangling over the weekend
latest is probably monday
well, if something is already "approved"
then the latest to actually get the thing landable is sunday then?
(and that leaves monday for wrestling with bors?)
ah, well, sort of - we want to produce stable artifacts by end of day monday
so ideally we'd fight bors as little as possible on monday
so when does the patch need to be merged into beta branch on github?
in order to make that End of Day monday deadline for stable artifacts?
I mean, we often do the final round as part of the promotion (it's also a bors build)
so it's kinda hard to say?
okay
if you want a hard deadline then I would say end of day sunday is the one I'd want
(If you cannot tell, I voiced a concern yesterday to @simulacrum that maybe I shuodn't have scheduled this meeting today after all)
(due to this beta backport stuff. Ah well.)
Anyway
One "big question" that @simulacrum put forward to me yesteday
is that this meeting slot doesn't necessarily have the stake-holders present
for this topic
In principle we could collectively review the site and discuss things we could change about it
Which stakeholders are not present?
So there are a couple different kinds of stake-holders I'm thinking of
There's the people who regularly use perf.rlo, (or would use it if issue X were addressed)
that is, people who in principle care about the compiler's performance trajectory
I'd like us to be specific about what (for lack of a better word) cohorts of people use perf.rlo.
Another kind of stake-holder are the people who we might expect to maintain or enhance perf.rlo

rylev said:

I'd like us to be specific about what (for lack of a better word) cohorts of people use perf.rlo.

In theory all the members of T-compiler should use perf.rlo, or some similar tool, to be aware of compiler's performance over time
(I don't know if they all do)

I had the following groups in mind:

 * Compiler team: curious as to the general trajectory of performance
 * Performance team: actively working to keep performance steady or to improve it
 * rustc devs who have the itch to work on performance 
 * Curious person who uses Rust
right
I suppose one might claim that tech leads for other projects
deciding whether to Rust
Yes good point
might also look at perf.rlo , in theory, to try to evaluate the claims that the compileris too slow
but I don't know if that 's realistic
in any case its a potential audience member to be aware of. But not one I'd want to be prioritizing our presentation for
I think it is reasonable to say that people interested in using Rust may want to look to see "are they doing work here", even if not necessarily to make a concrete claim
It's a bit difficult to judge, but it seems like we have a few people from at least the first three categories in this meeting.
Anyway, those two bigs groups: The viewers of perf.rlo, and the implementors of perf.rlo, are the two groups I'm concerned about
in terms of whether they're even at the meeitng
It seems unlikely we're going to get the majority of interested people from all of those groups into one synchronous meeting.
Even more specifically, I'm not sure we have serious "implementors" of perf.rlo beyond @simulacrum
which, if I'm correct about that assertion, is itself is a pretty big problem,

Yes, the reason being that I think there are roughly three buckets:

  • People who want to see the general state and trend of rustc perf: short, concise not too many details
  • People who want to see the general state in the short/medium term and need to know technical reasons for worsening performance
  • People who want to stay fully on top of performance
Right now, perf.rlo seems to only be serving the last group (and arguably not as well as it could)
So, what can/should we do in this meeting?
I suggest figuring out which of those cohorts we want to address and coming up with a plan for doing so
with what kind of timeline?
Set goals that are achievable in a month and schedule a followup
achievable by @simulacrum alone? Or are we going to enlist help?
I'd like to help
So lets take a quick poll
hmm what's best way to do this
I'm going to put a pair of emojis down
well
just add yourself to the raised pair of hands here if you think you can help during next month
(I deliberately didn't put down how much help)
I would very much like to but realistically I don't think I have time to help :(
okay. That's enough hands that I'm willing to entertain that it might pay off. :)

Wesley Wiser said:

I would very much like to but realistically I don't think I have time to help :(

realism is appreciated.
So okay, I'm now willing to believe that not all the hypothetical work would fall on @simulacrum 's lap.
so then lets talk goals for perf.rlo site itself then, in terms of who its audience is
first: Do people have other cohorts buckets to add to @rylev 's list?

pnkfelix said:

(I don't know if they all do)

If the primary interface is @rust-timer queue I would be surprised if there's anybody who hasn't used it, at least indirectly.
That's true: That's a common use I forgot to include
Namely, evaluating effects of a single proposed PR
(versus looking at trajectory over all time)
Which is I think a fourth bucket then, in terms of the audience for the site, right @rylev ?

pnkfelix said:

Namely, evaluating effects of a single proposed PR

This is probably what I use perf.rlo for 90% of the time.
Yes, that's another good one.
(of course it is better to have the other historical data when it comes to interpreting the effects of one PR)
(and thus this new bucket ends up blending into one of the other three)
I personally put myself into "People who want to see the general state in the short/medium term and need to know technical reasons for worsening performance"
and I think PR authors using @rust-timer queue are similar, in terms of what history they would be comparing against, right?
Can we expect to actually provide value for all three buckets, (if only via distinct views)?
I wanted to see historical data on the compare view for wall time of a PR I looked at yesterday.
I think yes, or at least, IMO we provide value to all 5 buckets
i.e., today
@rylev claimed above "Right now, perf.rlo seems to only be serving the last group (and arguably not as well as it could)"
where the last group was "People who want to stay fully on top of performance"
I guess I agree not as well as it could, but it seems like rust-timer queue is seeing active use (and presumably at least mildly successful use)
right. That represents a kind of success
I think it's extremely difficult to get a general idea of performance (for those who only care about general trends - see arewefastyet? for a better attempt at this)
The summary/graph views of the perf.rlo are pretty nice for a birds-view.
In terms of things we can accomplish in a month's time

And as for those who care about more technical trends it's possible to get that information, but it can be hard to see through the noise at times and the default view stresses only one aspect of performance (number of CPU instructions)
Maybe it's good to start by trying to assemble a concrete list of pain points?
(where, notably, we are planning to have our memory-usage sprint in a month)
maybe
Okay how about this
we dedicate five minutes now
where everyone gets to list pain points?
and then we have hard stop on that after those five minutes are
up
Pain point: Not clear which benchmarks matter. Am I supposed to weight all equally? (Does summary weight all equally?)
Pain point: noise, in particular on some benchmarks, is frequently present, and makes it easy to essentially ignore such benchmarks.
Pain point: the compare mode presentation, for each benchmark, has one "full" and then several incr variants. This might be leading to over-emphasis on incr performance.
Pain point: How do I tell what things are likely noise vs real gains and losses in performance
Pain point: too much data -- boiling data down to a view of "how is compiler doing". The dashboard helps here, but is it representative?
Pain point: regressions have unclear responsibility in terms of tracking down cause/fixing and deciding whether to revert. (is it the author? performance triager?)
Pain point: regressions during a rollup have unclear provenance
Pain point: hard to get a good overview of performance (of a particular diff) across many metric types (e.g.., wall time, cpu instructions, rss, etc.)
Pain point: who decides how much regression is "too much"?
Pain point: The detailed comparison view often does not correlate with summarized comparison view for small regressions/speedups.
Pain point: making decisions based on compare view often seems fairly arbitrary (eh, some minor regressions, some minor improvements, seems good enough :shrug:)
Pain point: We don't have disk space as metric. :)
One minute left

Pain point: "well known" that some components are causing major increases in timing (e.g., simd in core/std), but unclear if we can say "stop adding intrinsics" or how to evaluate the tradeoff between features and performance. particularly performance of rustc developers vs end users, too
Pain point: The impact of cgu partitioning is not controlled for, while introducing systematic bias in measurements.
Pain point: overwhelming for newcomers on how to understand what they're looking at
Pain point: no measurement of runtime performance of generated code (kind of orthogonal, kind of not)
Pain point: These are all measuring compiler's own performance. We don't keep historical data on performance of generated code itsef.
Wow
Okay that was great
Or at least cathartic
So we had some volunteers up above
Assuming that we agree on the bucketing/groups that @rylev posited above
My thinking is that we can either talk about which group to focus on during the next month
or we can talk about which specific pain points to focus on
but I don't know if we have time to realistically talk about both
From the talk above, it seems like perhaps the most impacted group could be the last one we pointed out: rustc devs who want to understand the impact of their changes on compiler performance
I think that's the logical group to focus on
Because @rust-timer queue is the most common use of perf.rlo today, you mean?
If we agree that's a good audience to focus on, can we pick pain points that impact that group?

pnkfelix said:

Because @rust-timer queue is the most common use of perf.rlo today, you mean?

Yes
given our narcisstic "roadmap goal" of improving the experience of compiler devs
I think that sounds excellent

nikomatsakis said:

given our narcisstic customer-focused "roadmap goal" of improving the experience of compiler devs
so AWS
okay
lol :) we kill me
what makes sense then? Put pain points into a doc and order them by priority?
(prioritizing according to benefit to rustc devs?)
Arguably that prioritization could be done by the volunteers
so really, what does this meeting need to discuss
there's not that much time left, too
I thik having a list of the pain points is already pretty valuable
Agreed
assembling them into a doc and maybe brainstorming (not synchronously?) about how to attack them night be useful, prioritization seems good too
So I'm inferring that we may need a project group
from the people who raised their :raised_hands: before
is there anyone who would be willing to co-lead a group?
I'd be willing to co-lead
(I'm willing to be co-lead with it, at least I think I can do that this month)
(argably @simulacrum is ideal co-lead instead of me, but I do not want to put more on their plate)
Okay great @rylev
I threw the list of pain points in the doc
is there anyone else who might like to co-lead with @rylev instead of me?
what about #t-infra ?
I don't think I can effectively lead, probably have roughly 1-1.5 hours per week at most
While @simulacrum is the logical choice, I think having new people will be good.
@oliver do you mean we should be engaging with T-infra?
enlisting help there? asking permission?
all of the above perhaps
or just having the conversation over in that Zulip channel? :laughing:
I do not think T-infra will have much of an opinion or ability to help.

simulacrum said:

I threw the list of pain points in the doc

thanks for doing that
okay. Well it sounds to me like @rylev and I will co-lead a project group here
I am EXCITED :tada:
There's a lot of other stuff that was in the agenda notes
the one big one I wanted to point out
is that we may want to enlist Data Science expertise of some kind
I don't know if we have much "in house"
but we all might have networks on which we can reach out
(at least, I intend to do so at my job)
beyond that, I think @rylev and I will be in touch with the people who put up their :raised_hands: up above.
to find out availability and interest/expertise etc
Anything else anyone wants to add before we call it quits for this meeting and I can go figure out why tidy is yelling at me?

pnkfelix said:

is that we may want to enlist Data Science expertise of some kind

oooh
Do we continue a discussion of next steps async on #t-compiler/performance ?
this sounds like a really good idea

rylev said:

Do we continue a discussion of next steps async on #t-compiler/performance ?

I think that makes sense.
I made a topic over at #t-compiler/performance > lets keep talking about perf.rlo
so anyone who wants to lurk can do so
I think that's it for the meeting. There's more discussion continuing in that topic. Thanks for attending everyone! :wave:

oh yeah, sorry, I got so into the follow-on discussion in #t-compiler/performance > lets keep talking about perf.rlo that I forgot about this topic. Sorry all! Thanks to you all for attending and for @Wesley Wiser for following up on ending it. :smile:
